sentence: Procter & Gamble ( PG ) shareholders narrowly rejected activist investor Nelson Peltz's bid for a board seat to help shake up the business after a costly proxy fight.
P&G shares reversed lower, undercutting a buy point.
[ibd-display-video id=2345484 width=50 float=left autostart=true]The outcome was close and Trian says it will await the certified results.
Peltz's Trian Funds owns a $3.5 billion stake in the maker of Tide detergent, Crest toothpaste and many more.
Peltz argues that P&G has been too focused on legacy core brands and not enough on young, innovative products.
He also wants P&G to reorganize its 10 units into just three: beauty, grooming and health care; fabric and home care and baby, feminine and family care.
P&G says core brands are still important, and noted the release of products such as Tide Pods in 2012.
The Dow component argues that the corporate reorganizing would add to costs.
The expensive feud has been brewing since February, when Peltz revealed the big P&G stake.
Trian officially nominated Peltz for the board in July.
The big three proxy advisories - Egan-Jones, Glass Lewis and Institutional Shareholder Services - favored putting Peltz on the board.
Procter & Gamble shares, which had risen above their 50-day moving average, fell as low as 89.86 after the vote's results, closing down 0.5% at 91.62 on the stock market today .
P&G is now back below a buy range from a 92.10 entry initially cleared in mid-August.
